metadata.titleEn: Ar-Ar age data of Muscovite  of the west 509 Daoban Li-Be rare metal deposit in the West Kunlun Orogenic Belt (2022)
metadata.description: Three Muscovite were collected from 509 Banxi lithium beryllium rare metal mine, The 40Ar/39Ar dating data of Muscovite in spodumene-bearing pegmatite veins show that the crystallization age of the minerals is 188Ma, indicates that regional temperature for this area kept as 350℃ for 30Myr, and this thermal environment is conducive to the evolution and crystallization of granite-pegmatite system.. In combination of the regional orogeny (ca. 210~200Ma) of the Paleo-Tethys, the geological features as well as the ore-forming ages demonstrate that the tectonic environment of West Kunlun and Karakunlun was post collision extension during 188Ma, which is a favorable condition for the element enrichment and mineralization in Dahongliutan rare metal ore field. This understanding has practical significance for regional metallogenic potential evaluation and prospecting.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to determine the Ar-Ar dating of muscovite in rare metal deposits?
Feature Specification.Answer: 40Ar/39Ar dating, 188Ma crystallization age, cooled to around 350℃, 30Myr period

Quantification.Question: How many white mica samples were collected for Ar-Ar age data in the 西昆仑509道班西锂铍稀有金属矿?

Comparison.Question: How does the Ar-Ar dating method used for determining the age of muscovite in rare metal mineral deposits compare to other radiometric dating techniques in terms of accuracy and application in geological studies?
Comparison.Answer: The Ar-Ar dating method used for determining the age of muscovite provides specific crystallization ages, such as the 188 Ma for the muscovite in the rare metal mineral deposits, highlighting its effectiveness in showing the duration of geological cooling processes. This method is particularly suited for analyzing the thermal history and tectonic environments, such as the post-collision extension phase observed in the context of the Western Kunlun-Karakoram region. In comparison, other radiometric techniques might vary in their precision, sample applicability, and the type of geological history they can reveal.

Interpretation.Question: What can the Ar-Ar dating of muscovite reveal about the geological processes and the thermal history of the rare metal mineral deposits in the 西昆仑509道班西 region?
Interpretation.Answer: The Ar-Ar dating of muscovite indicates that the mineral crystallization age is 188 million years ago, suggesting that the regional environment was cooling to 350°C over a period of up to 30 million years. This prolonged thermal environment was conducive to the evolution and crystallization of the granite-pegmatite system. Additionally, the combination of this data with the historical evolution of the Paleo-Tethys orogeny (210-200 million years ago) suggests that the 西昆仑-喀喇昆仑 region was in a post-collisional extensional tectonic environment at 188 million years, which created favorable conditions for the enrichment and mineralization of rare metal deposits in the 大红柳滩 area.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contributed to the determination of the 188Ma mineral crystallization age using the 40Ar/39Ar dating method for white mica in a rare metal ore environment?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The determination of the 188Ma mineral crystallization age using the 40Ar/39Ar dating method for white mica was influenced by the cooling of the regional environment to 350℃ over a period of 30 million years. This prolonged thermal environment was conducive to the evolution and crystallization of the granite-pegmatite system, in the context of the post-collision extensional tectonic environment during the evolutionary history of the regional Paleo-Tethys orogeny.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using Ar-Ar dating data on white mica to understand the cooling history of geological environments in rare metal mineralization areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of Ar-Ar dating data on white mica can reveal the mineral crystallization age, showing how long the regional environment remained at certain temperatures, such as 350℃. This understanding can indicate the duration of favorable conditions for the evolution and crystallization of granite-pegmatite systems, which in turn can help assess the mineralization potential and guide exploration efforts in rare metal mineralization fields.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of determining the Ar-Ar age of white mica in rare metal deposits to understand regional geological evolution and mineralization potential?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to identify the crystallization age of minerals, which indicates that the regional environment cooled to 350℃ around 188Ma, lasting for 30 million years. This thermal condition is conducive to the evolution and crystallization of the granite-pegmatite system. By correlating with the history of the regional Paleo-Tethys orogeny (210~200Ma), it is concluded that the area was in a post-collision extensional tectonic environment during 188Ma, creating favorable conditions for element enrichment and mineralization in the Dahongliutan rare metal ore field, thus supporting mineral potential evaluation and exploration.
